Yesterday, I saw "Lucy", AL 288-1, at the Museum of Natural History in Houston. Houston is the first stop on her planned 5 yr. walkabout in the U.S. After leaving Houston at the end of April of 2008, she will also visit Washington, New York, Denver and Chicago.
 
 Before I got to "Lucy", I passed through an exhibit of many wondrous and beautiful artifacts from Ethiopia from centuries past. I appreciated the various short films throughout the exhibit. While the typical view of Ethiopia has been that of a country of starvation and war, that has not always been the case, and it is no longer true. And while Hadar appears desolate, much of the country is beautiful. But still I was in a hurry to see Lucy.
 
 At one point there is a display case with 5 really good replicas of hominid fossils, three of which I recognized as OH-5, KNM-ER 3733, and KNM-ER 1813. The others were familiar but I can't remember which they were. I intend to pay my respects to Lucy again with a pen and paper and take notes. I was just so excited on this first visit that I didn't think to take notes.
 
 Finally, at the end of the exhibition came Lucy. At the far end of the penultimate room was a sign with an arrow - "<- Lucy". Starting at the left of the door was a large, semi-circular panoramic depiction of hominid species that extended through almost 180 degrees, with discussion and explanation below. Just to the left of the center of the room was a life size replica of what Lucy may have looked like (reconstructed from the fossils of more than 300 individuals that have been recovered). To the right of center was a display of reproductions of the fossil boned suspended in their relative positions. You can see that exhibit on Wikipedia.
 
 In the center of the room was Lucy. She in what appeared to be a massive wooden case with glass (I suspect it isn't the glass you have in your home windows) on 5 sides. She was reclining on a bed of green felt. I spent a lot of time looking at her.
 
 On point of particular interest was the distal ends of the ulnas. I'm not an anatomist, but I did make an effort use the Internet to observe the wrist structure of humans before my visit. The distal ends of the ulna are not the same. I couldn't find any examples in chimps, but as I understand it, that peculiar protrusion that Lucy has would have prevented her from flexing her wrist backwards. In chimps and gorillas (as I understand it), a similar protrusion locks the wrist to enable knuckle walking.
 
 For the creationists aboard, let me explain. Pretend that you are a football (American) lineman. Get down in a stance and put your knuckles on the ground. Now relax and let the heel of your hand touch the ground. A chimpanzee can't do that - and neither could Lucy.
 
 After I look further into the matter and find the best pictures I can find of the distal end of the ulna of a human and a chimp, are less than adequate. I'm going to go back to visit Lucy. My problem is a good picture of a the distal end of a chimp ulna.
 
 I spent some time observing Lucy and explaining various anatomical characteristics to others who were there.
 
 When I go back, I'm going to be armed with pictures and a magnifying glass.
 
 Visiting Lucy was an amazing experience! In my more than 40 years as a biologist and the 30 or so years since Lucy was discovered, I never hoped to be able to actually see such a specimen.

 No, no, I am not saying that all fossil fuels are from sea animals and sea vegetation, though some would be. Land vegetation is a very large source of fossil fuels. There would be far more land vegetation than dinosaur in fossil fuels. If you think about a common tree, it spends its lifetime absorbing carbon-dioxide through photosynthesis (okay at night it absorbs oxygen and releases carbon dioxide, but most of the time . . . ). So, enormous amounts of carbon are trapped in trees, which is why rainforests are so important, and other forests too. However, animals don't collect large amounts of carbon (though they are carbon based). It is this carbon that is so important.
 
 For millions of years, plants collected up unimaginable amounts of carbon and locked it away. Then over the last century or so, we have developed the technology to suck up all this locked up carbon and release it into the atmosphere, and we are now worried that we are running short. So, each year we are releasing the carbon into the atmosphere that took hundreds of thousands of years to be collected by ancient vegetation. Do you see a possible problem here?
 
 And yes, coal and natural gas are also mostly plant based. Lots more stored carbon.
 
 It is probably true that animals do end up in your gas tank, but far more decomposed plant is in there. If you think about a forest or a jungle, you'll probably see far more vegetation that animals life. That's where most of the carbon is, and that the useful bit.

 Oil Drillers Strike World's Deepest Dinosaur
 James Owen
 for National Geographic News
 April 26, 2006
 
 Oil drillers have struck dinosaur off Norway, the Research Council of Norway announced this week.
 
 Found 1.4 miles (2.3 kilometers) beneath the North Sea, the fossil find marks the world's deepest known dinosaur, researchers say.
 
 Furthermore, it's the first ever dinosaur for Norway. 
 
 The fossil has been identified as the knucklebone of a Plateosaurus, a massive, plant-munching dino that lived some 200 million years ago.
 
 The discovery was made about 87 miles (140 kilometers) west of Norway in the Snorre oil field. Geologists Morten Bergan and Johan Petter Nystuen spotted a bone-like fragment in a drill core-a long cylinder of rock from an oil exploration well.
 
 A dinosaur fossil has never been found so far underground, says Jørn Hurum of the Natural History Museum, University of Oslo. 
 
 "It's a very small piece of bone-about three centimeters [1.2 inches]," he said. 
 
 Hurum, as Norway's only dinosaur researcher, had the difficult task of trying to identify the find. He took a slice from the fossil just a few thousandth of a millimeter thick for microscopic examination. 
 
 German Fossils
 
 While the examination confirmed the remains as a dinosaur's, it wasn't until Hurum compared the fossil with specimens in Germany that he made the link.
 
 Plateosaurus was a giant, long-necked plant-eater that grew 30 feet (9.1 meters) long and weighed as much as four tons (4.1 metric tons). An early dinosaur, it is known to have lived in modern-day Europe and Greenland between 210 and 195 million years ago.
 
 "Plateosaurs have a special kind of bone structure which is not seen in any other dinosaurs from this period," Hurum said. "They were one of the most common dinosaurs. Hundreds of skeletons have been found in Europe."
 
 The fossil came from sandstone sediments left by prehistoric rivers that once meandered through dry plains.
 
 "At that time there was no North Sea," Hurum said. "There was a semi-desert between Norway and Greenland, so it was a dry, arid climate like you see in Morocco today."
 
 The researcher says most of the oil fields in the North Sea are in marine sediments rather than in sandstones that were formed on land, and that other deep drilling has yielded fragments of prehistoric sea creatures. 
 
 Marine Reptiles
 
 "We got several drill cores which had fossils of marine reptiles," Hurum added. "Finding a terrestrial animal is much more rare-its like looking for a needle in ten haystacks." 
 
 Being Norway's sole dino researcher, he appropriately played a hand in uncovering the nation's only known dinosaur.
 
 The country's distinct lack of dinosaur remains is attributed to the Ice Age, which obliterated rock formations that might have harbored these fossils. 
 
 "Most of the rocks in Norway are twice as old as the oldest dinosaur or much older," Hurum said. "All the young rocks were removed and eroded away by the glaciers."
 
 He says mainland Norway has a fine fossil record in rocks between 540 and 400 million years old, including marine trilobites and primitive, squid-like species. 
 
 "The only way for us to find a dinosaur is [drilling] in the North Sea," Hurum added. 
 
 Nystuen, co-finder of the fossil and a geologist at the University of Oslo, says North Sea oil exploration may well add to Norway's dinosaur collection. 
 
 "But," he admitted, "they will be very hard to find and extremely expensive to recover from their very deep tombs."

Wow! This thread has gone way, way off topic. I'm not actually a stickler for keeping any thread strictly to the topic of the OP, since I feel that discussion may logically lead far afield. That seems to be the case here. It seems that this discussion has revealed the scientific ignorance of one particular creationist parrot.
 
 However, rather than start a new thread, I thought that it might be more appropriate to update this one.
 
 I revisited the Houston Museum of Natural Science. This time I took my younger son, an Army SSG, home on convelescent leave. This time I went armed to answer the questions that I had from my first visit.
 
 Early in the exhibit there is a a representation of Lucy's skull, showing Lucy's bones that have been found. Note the similarity to the Australopithecus afarensis composite reconstruction that is built using the principles of bilateral symmetry from 12 A. afarensis skull fossils. Note the transitional nature of the specimens. Apelike brow ridges, low skull vault, large mandible, projecting lower face, no chin, as compared with the much reduced canines and the foramen magnum, located under (rather than at the back of) the skull.
 
 Just before the "Lucy room", there was a case with six (not 5 as I previously reported) excellent reproductions of hominid skull fossils. I took notes this time and can now identify each reproduction as follows:
 
 KNM ER 406 (Paranthropus boisei) 1.7 ma male.
 
 OH 5 (Paranthropus boisei) 1.8 ma Orig. Zinjanthropus boisei, then Australopithecus boisei male.
 
 KNM ER 732 (Paranthropus boisei) 1.7 ma female. 
 
 KNM ER 1813 (Homo habilis) 1.9 ma
 
 KNM ER 3733 (Homo ergaster) 1.75 ma
 
 Peking Man (Weidenreich Reconstruction) 500-230 ka
 
 But those reproductions were a matter of personal curiosity more than anything else. What I really wanted to see was the small protrusion claimed to be present in Lucy that is at the base of the ulna typical of knuckle walkers. I came with high-res photos of the bones of the human wrist that I laid down on the glass above Lucy's bones. There was that peculiar protrusion at the base of Lucy's ulna that was not present in the photo of the bones of a human wrist. That protrusion is present in knuckle walking apes and Lucy. And yet, Lucy was not a knuckle walker. Her arms were too short, her pelvis was wrong (more like bi-pedals), the angle of the head of the femur indicates that it slanted inward from the hip to place the knee under the body, and the angle of the femur with the shin indicates the same. These are characteristic of a bipedal animal. Thus, as might be expected in a transitional species, Lucy's arms were proportionally longer than ours but shorter than extant apes, her fingers were longer and more curved, making her a better climber. But her pelvis, hip, knee, spine, and skull show that she walked on two legs.
 
 Oh, yeah. Here's Lucy.
 
 Lucy

 I still love Lucy. I have read more about her with the possible exceptions of Charles Darwin and Jesus Christ.
